{{merge to|Celebrity|discuss=Talk:Celebrity#Proposed merge with Celebrity Privacy|date=November 2018}} {{essay-like|date=November 2018}} '''Celebrity privacy''' is the right of people who gain high fame and recognition on [[mass media]], usually entertainment stars, sports athletes or political leaders, to hide the information they are not willing to disclose to the public. The privacy of celebrities includes many different aspects, such as the celebrities' address, family members and romantic relationships. Different from the privacy of the general public, celebrity privacy is usually challenged by the press and the fans: [[paparazzi]] chase celebrities' cars to take private photos and sell them to entertainment magazines for profits<ref name=":102">{{Cite journal|last=Nordhaus|first=Jamie|date=|title=Celebrities' Rights to Privacy: How Far Should the Paparazzi Be Allowed to Go?|url=http://connection.ebscohost.com/c/articles/6935518/celebrities-rights-privacy-how-far-should-paparazzi-be-allowed-go|journal=Review of Litigation|volume=18|pages=285-231|via=}}</ref>; some fans break into celebrity’s house or stalk, kidnap or even assassinate them.<ref name=":32">{{Cite journal|last=Hoffmann|first=Jens|date=2009-07-03|title=Public Figures and Stalking in the European Context|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2Fs10610-009-9104-0|journal=European Journal on Criminal Policy and Research|language=en|volume=15|issue=3|pages=293–305|doi=10.1007/s10610-009-9104-0|issn=0928-1371}}</ref> To prevent celebrity privacy, some national and state governments set up privacy laws particularly for protecting celebrities<ref name=":17">{{Cite journal|last=M.|first=Locke, Christina|last2=Carnley|first2=Murrhee, Kara|date=|title=Is Driving with the Intent to Gather News a Crime? The Chilling Effects of California’s Anti-Paparazzi Legislation|url=https://digitalcommons.lmu.edu/elr/vol31/iss2/1/|journal=Loyola of Los Angeles Entertainment Law Review|language=en|volume=31|issue=2}}</ref>. However, the legal impact of these celebrity privacy laws has currently been undetermined, since the curb for celebrity privacy intrusion often counteracts the legal principle of “free press” in many countries.<ref name=":162">{{Cite journal|last=Azriel|first=Joshua|date=2016-10-04|title=Reining in the California Paparazzi: An Analysis of the California Legislature's Attempts to Safeguard Celebrity Privacy|url=https://escholarship.org/uc/item/4wd447bs|journal=California Journal of Politics and Policy|language=en|volume=8|issue=4|doi=10.5070/p2cjpp8432756|issn=1944-4370}}</ref><ref name=":152">{{Cite journal|date=|title=Privacy, Technology, and the California "Anti-Paparazzi" Statute|url=http://www.jstor.org/stable/1342388|journal=Harvard Law Review|volume=112|issue=6|pages=1367–1384|doi=10.2307/1342388}}</ref> == Debate == Scholars have debated how much or what type of privacy celebrities and their friends or family can or should expect.<ref name=":02">{{Cite journal|last=McNamara|first=Kim|date=2009-02-01|title=Publicising private lives: celebrities, image control and the reconfiguration of public space|url=https://doi.org/10.1080/14649360802553178|journal=Social & Cultural Geography|language=en|volume=10|issue=1|pages=9–23|doi=10.1080/14649360802553178|issn=1464-9365}}</ref> Commonly posed arguments center upon topics such as the idea of celebrity privacy as controlled publicity, the intrusion of paparazzi or fans, and what types of privacy should be granted to and expected by children of celebrities.<ref name=":102" />
=== Celebrity privacy as a controlled publicity === In order to keep high public exposure and show positive professional images, celebrities and their teams often intentionally manage or control how their private lives are presented to the public.<ref name=":102" /> According to attorney Jamie Nordhaus, the boundaries of privacy and publicity for celebrities can become blurred, as they most are always watched by fans, paparazzi, and other potential stalkers.<ref name=":102" /> Some celebrities remain conscious of maintaining a public persona when they are in the public eye as opposed to a personal one in private and will negotiate with the press to release staged private life photos.<ref name=":102" /> Jens Hoffman has argued that celebrity attempts to sacrifice their privacy for publicity may result in a loss of legal protections, as celebrities claiming that an invasion of privacy by the press could be seen as utilizing media in order to achieve or maintain fame.<ref name=":32" /> The latter argument was used in a court decision on a stolen sex tape that featured American actress [[Pamela Anderson|Pamela Anderson Lee]] and her then-boyfriend [[Bret Michaels]].<ref name=":62">{{Cite journal|last=Hong|first=Seong|last2=Hong|first2=Seong Choul|date=2016-04-07|title=Kids Sell: Celebrity Kids’ Right to Privacy|url=https://www.mdpi.com/2075-471X/5/2/18|journal=Laws|language=en|volume=5|issue=2|pages=18|doi=10.3390/laws5020018}}</ref> Lee had sued [[Internet Entertainment Group]] (IEG) and [[Paramount Network|Paramount]] for broadcasting a story in 1998, that contained excerpts from the tape, however the court considered her as voluntarily sacrificing her privacy in order to publicize herself.<ref name=":62" /> Scholar Seong Hong has stated that based on the court decision, Lee’s privacy right was not protected because of her celebrity identity.<ref name=":62" />
=== Intrusion by paparazzi and fans ===
==== Paparazzi ==== [[File:Princess_diana_bristol_1987_crop.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Princess_diana_bristol_1987_crop.jpg|thumb|Princess Diana]] The term “[[paparazzi]]”’ is used to define the [[Freelance photographer|freelance photographers]] who take celebrities’ exclusive pictures and sell them to the press for financial purposes.<ref name=":102" /> Techniques used by the paparazzi include [[stalking]] celebrities and their children, taking photos of them with or without consent, and chasing celebrities’ cars.<ref name=":112">{{Cite journal|last=Hindman|first=Elizabeth Blanks|date=2003-09-01|title=The Princess and the Paparazzi: Blame, Responsibility, and the Media's Role in the Death of Diana|url=http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1177/107769900308000311|journal=Journalism & Mass Communication Quarterly|language=en|volume=80|issue=3|pages=666–688|doi=10.1177/107769900308000311|issn=1077-6990}}</ref><ref name=":92">{{Cite journal|last=Mortensen|first=Mette|last2=Jerslev|first2=Anne|date=2013-09-30|title=Taking the extra out of the extraordinary: Paparazzi photography as an online celebrity news genre|url=https://journals.sagepub.com/action/captchaChallenge?redirectUri=%2Fdoi%2F10.1177%2F1367877913503425|journal=International Journal of Cultural Studies|language=en|volume=17|issue=6|pages=619–636|doi=10.1177/1367877913503425|issn=1367-8779}}</ref> Some see these techniques as causing turbulence to the lives of the celebrities and those with them and that some aggressive techniques may result in the injury or death of the celebrity.<ref name=":112" /> The [[death of Diana, Princess of Wales]], has been cited as an example of the risks of paparazzi techniques.<ref name=":112" /> Besides, scholar Elizabeth Hindman claims that the sale of exaggerated content without context to sensationalize particular moments has decreased credibility in the news industry.<ref name=":102" /><ref name=":92" />
According to Ray Murray's research, some paparazzi will “draw an ethical line” by abiding by specific rules and in a series of paparazzi interviews, most of the participants claimed that they would not break the law, and some attested that they would not take any photo of celebrity children without consent.<ref name=":72">{{Cite journal|last=Murray|first=Ray|date=2011-03-11|title=Stalking the Paparazzi: A View from a Different Angle|url=https://doi.org/10.1080/15551393.2011.548724|journal=Visual Communication Quarterly|language=en|volume=18|issue=1|pages=4–17|doi=10.1080/15551393.2011.548724|issn=1555-1393}}</ref> Scholar Andrew Mendelson argues that paparazzi are valuable in that they reveal potential mismatches between the public image and the reality of celebrities who possess great power in contemporary society, which legitimizes the paparazzi's invasion of celebrity privacy as a form of [[watchdog journalism]].<ref name=":82">{{Cite journal|last=Mendelson|first=Andrew L.|date=2007-09-01|title=On the function of the United States paparazzi: mosquito swarm or watchdogs of celebrity image control and power|url=https://www.tandfonline.com/action/captchaChallenge?redirectUri=%2Fdoi%2Fabs%2F10.1080%2F14725860701507230|journal=Visual Studies|language=en|volume=22|issue=2|pages=169–183|doi=10.1080/14725860701507230|issn=1472-586X}}</ref> Besides, Anne Jerslev and Mette Mendelson have noted that the paparazzi have become integrated into the mainstream culture and their photographs are distributed widely and quickly by consumers.<ref name=":92" />
==== Fans ==== The “dual entertainment path model” suggested by scholar Kineta Hung shows that [[Fan (person)|fans]] and non-fans adopt different ways to engage with their favorite celebrities <ref name=":22">{{Cite journal|last=Hung|first=Kineta|date=2014-04-03|title=Why Celebrity Sells: A Dual Entertainment Path Model of Brand Endorsement|url=https://www.tandfonline.com/action/captchaChallenge?redirectUri=%2Fdoi%2Fabs%2F10.1080%2F00913367.2013.838720|journal=Journal of Advertising|language=en|volume=43|issue=2|pages=155–166|doi=10.1080/00913367.2013.838720|issn=0091-3367}}</ref> For non-fans, they usually pay attention to celebrities and the released news to escape from boredom. In contrast, Hung theorizes that fans put a much higher emotional investment in order to create an individual “bond” with celebrities, which gives them pleasure and a sense of satisfaction.<ref name=":22" /> According to Hung, fans may typically try to become physically and mentally closer to their idols by attending concerts, movies, and fan-meetings. In extreme circumstances, fans may become obsessed with celebrities and invade their privacy by [[stalking]] them.<ref name=":22" /> Scholar Jens Hoffman has argued that this is a result of a pathological fixation, as fans exhibiting this can believe that there is a special connection between their favorite celebrities and themselves, even though such a relationship does not exist in reality.<ref name=":32" /> Once unsatisfied, this fixation can lead fans to invade celebrity privacy out of disappointment and resentment.<ref name=":32" />
In South Korean culture, a fan who is overly interested in the private lives of [[Korean idol|K-POP idols]] or other public figure is called a "[[Sasaeng fan|Sasaeng fan"]], which means "private life fan" in English.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://grantland.com/hollywood-prospectus/k-pop/|title=Hallyu Tsunami: The Unstoppable (and Terrifying) Rise of K-Pop Fandom|last=Lansky|first=Sam|date=2012-09-10|work=Grantland|access-date=2018-11-28|language=en-US}}</ref> According to a study by William Patrick and Samantha Xiang, Sasaeng fans are typically teenage girls between 13-22 years old, and their common stalking behaviors include installing [[Hidden camera|hidden cameras]] in idols’ home, chasing idols’ car at high speed, and stealing personal things from idols’ room.<ref name=":42">{{Cite journal|last=Williams|first=J. Patrick|last2=Ho|first2=Samantha Xiang Xin|date=2015-10-16|title=“Sasaengpaen” or K-pop Fan? Singapore Youths, Authentic Identities, and Asian Media Fandom|url=https://doi.org/10.1080/01639625.2014.983011|journal=Deviant Behavior|language=en|volume=37|issue=1|pages=81–94|doi=10.1080/01639625.2014.983011|issn=0163-9625}}</ref> Sasaeng fans are viewed negatively in South Korea due to actions such as poisoning members of a disliked K-POP idol or using bodily fluids to write letters to the object of their affections.<ref name="yahoo12">{{cite web|url=http://sg.entertainment.yahoo.com/blogs/singapore-showbiz/sasaeng-groupies-gone-wild-part-1-k-fans-141105992.html|title=Sasaeng Stalkers (Part 1): K-pop fans turn to blood, poison for attention|last=Soh|first=Elizabeth|date=2012-08-02|website=Yahoo! Singapore|publisher=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=2017-05-24}}</ref>
=== Celebrity Children === The public interest in the private lives of celebrities has prompted [[paparazzi]] to catch specific and trivial details of celebrities’ daily lives, which includes the lives of their children.<ref name=":52">{{Cite journal|last=Marôpo|first=Lidia|last2=Jorge|first2=Ana|date=2014-11-01|title=At the heart of celebrity: celebrities’ children and their rights in the media|url=http://www.unav.es/fcom/communication-society/en/resumen.php?art_id=510|journal=Communication & Society|language=en|volume=27|issue=4|pages=17–31|doi=10.15581/003.27.4.17-32|issn=2386-7876}}</ref> Paparazzi photographs of these children are frequently posted in magazines, sometimes with friends or family, and often portray the celebrity and children's fame and lifestyles as high-quality and luxurious. These images can be either authorized or unauthorized.<ref name=":52" /> Seong Hong claims that due to the circulation of celebrity children photos, the media leads the public to establish a pseudo-relationship with celebrity children and imagine them as “our children”.<ref name=":62" /> This public imagination combined with the potentially constant presence of paparazzi has been seen as having the potential to threaten the privacy of celebrity children.<ref name=":52" />
==== Positive and negative effects ==== According to Lidia Maropo and Ana Jorge, celebrity children usually appear on newspapers and magazines together with their families: moments like celebrity children playing the park, having a picnic with the whole families or just hanging out with their parents are posted on media, which reflects the importance of children in the family and advocates for a more harmonious family relationship.<ref name=":52" /> At the same time, the celebrity children photos also suggest a pleasant experience and a sense of satisfaction of being a parent.<ref name=":52" /> The circulation of celebrity children images attracts the public to focus on the [[Family Relationship|family relationship]] and makes them realize the happiness brought by children and the responsibility of parents.<ref name=":52" />
The exposure of celebrity children to the public can result in the invasion of their [[Privacy|privacy rights]]. For example, the old son of [[Aircraft pilot|aviator]] [[Charles Lindbergh|Charles A. Lindbergh]], who became a national celebrity after he created records for flying from the U.S to France in 1927, was kidnapped and murdered in 1932. After this tragedy, Jon, Lindbergh’s second son, was chased continuously by paparazzi’s cars. To protect Jon, Lindbergh finally decided not to raise legal appealing but to move outside of the U.S with his family.<ref name=":62" /> Additionally, some celebrities will send photos of their children to media in order to prevent paparazzi from continuing disrupting their private lives: American film celebrities [[David Arquette]] and [[Courteney Cox]] released the photo of their daughter Coco to the press, which prevented them from being chased by paparazzi.<ref name=":62" />
==== Legal Protection regarding Children Privacy ==== ===== The United Nations ===== The United Nations Convention on the [[Children's rights|Rights of the Child]] (UNCRC) was permitted in 1989 as human rights started to gain more attention globally.<ref name=":52" /> This treaty deals with the most fundamental issue between children and the media, such as [[Freedom of speech|free expression]], non-discrimination and respect. Article 16, in particular, set that children have the right to protect themselves when encountering illegal interference of privacy or attacks on reputation.<ref name=":52" /> All the [[United Nations|UN]] countries, except U.S and [[Somalia]], approved and sighed this treaty.
===== United States ===== Seong Hong argues that in the United States, the celebrity children privacy has been rarely protected by U.S law currently.<ref name=":62" /> The main reason is that the legal protection of celebrity children is too narrow and it might counteract with the [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]], which emphasizes “free press” to encourage democratic voices.<ref name=":62" /> However, as the [[California]] Anti-Paparazzi Act was introduced, some celebrities suggested the [[State governments of the United States|state government]] to put more focus on celebrity children: actress [[Halle Berry]] hoped that the law could restrict paparazzi from approaching celebrity children since her children were afraid of going to school and trips due to the stalking of paparazzi.<ref name=":62" /> Besides, scholar Joshua Azriel suggests that there should be a full ban on the photos of celebrity children with stronger punishment.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Berkowitz|first=Dayna|date=|title=Stop the 'Nazzi': Why the United States Needs a Full Ban on Paparazzi Photographs of Children of Celebrities|url=https://digitalcommons.lmu.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1608&context=elr|journal=Loyola of Los Angeles Entertainment Law Review|volume=37|pages=175-206|via=}}</ref>
===== Brazil ===== In [[Brazil]], the Child and Adolescent Statute (ECA in Portuguese acronym) both directly and indirectly addressed the relationship between children and media.<ref name=":52" /> ECA grants the fundamental civil and human rights to children, including free expression and the right of image, idea and identity, etc. Article 18, in particular, emphasizes that everyone has the responsibility to protect the dignity of children and to save them from any violent or terrifying situation.<ref name=":52" /> Besides, Article 74-80 provides children with legal protection to harmful public media, such as violent television show.<ref name=":52" />
===== Portugal ===== In [[Portugal]], the Law for Protection of Children and Youth at Risk (LPCJP in Portuguese acronym) protects children from media that brings risky elements, such as violence or inhumanity. Besides, The Young Offenders’ Law prohibits media from identifying youngsters from 12-16 who commit illegal actions.<ref name=":52" />
== Celebrity Privacy Laws Around the World == === United States === ==== California “Anti-Paparazzi” Law ==== ===== History ===== In October 1997, [[Diana, Princess of Wales|Princess Diana]] died from a car accident in [[France]] which was suspected to be caused by seven paparazzi. Although the judge clarified later that the drunk driver rather than paparazzi caused the accident, [[Government of California|California government]] was aware of the danger brought by paparazzi and thus quickly set the first anti-paparazzi law.<ref name=":17" />
In 1998, California set the “invasion of privacy statute”, which prohibited the use of digital devices to take photos of celebrities on private occasions. However, this statute is criticized by opponents who believe it might inhibit the freedom of the press to gather news. Also, the language used was considered too broad and vague. Some media attorneys described the statute as a “[[Pandora's box|Pandora’s box]]” that brought a large number of severe problems.<ref name=":17" />
The First Amendment of the “invasion of privacy statute” was passed in 2005, which regulated that the profits from photos taken during altercations between celebrities and photographers will be forfeited. In 2009, another new law A.B 524 stated that up to $50,000 penalties would be charged from the first publishers of the photos taken in the ways that violate the privacy statute. This law aimed to stop the paparazzi who take private photos of celebrities for profit-gaining reasons. However, scholar Christina Locke and Kara Murrhee claims that the law is not effective because the first publishers of celebrity photos can usually make over a million dollars. Furthermore, A.B 524 seemly contradicts the [[Supreme Court of the United States|Supreme Court]] again for prohibiting the press to gain news legally.<ref name=":17" />
Since California noticed that confrontations between celebrities and paparazzi still happened and were even exacerbated, in January 2010, another anti-paparazzi law A.B 2479 was passed to address two main problems: paparazzi’s car-chasing which often leads to accidents and their behaviors that prevent the celebrities from moving freely. A.B 2479 further established both financial and criminal penalties for people who result in reckless driving because of the intention to gain photos or recording of other people for commercial purpose—the fine will be between $145 to $1,000, and the term of imprisonment will be between 5-90 days.<ref name=":162" /> If any child is inside the car during the [[reckless driving]], the fine will be up to $5,000 and the term of [[imprisonment]] will be up to one year. Also, to curb the paparazzi from encompassing the celebrities and thus prevent them from moving freely, the law counts this behavior as false imprisonment that allows for extra damages.<ref name=":17" />
===== Debate ===== The supporters of A.B 2479 were [[The City of Los Angeles]], [[Screen Actors Guild]] and Paparazzi Reform Initiative. They argued that the series of aggressive behaviors of paparazzi, such as parking their cars to block the celebrities’ cars or crowding the celebrities in public spaces like airports and entrances to public facilities have seriously disrupted celebrities’ private lives. On the contrary, [[California Newspaper Publishers Association]] (CNPA) opposed the bill since it undermines the activity of the press to gather news freely. Also, CNPA argued that the penalties for reckless driving targeted to journalists are unfair. According to Christina Locke and Kara Murrhee, even though compared to previous bills, A.B 2479 has made significant changes regarding focuses, the conflict between the California anti-paparazzi law and the First Amendment of Constitution still exists.<ref name=":17" />
==== "Anti-Paparazzi law" vs. The First Amendment ==== Keith Willis claims that in the U.S legal system, the conflict between the right to privacy and the right to free expression exists.<ref name=":122">{{Cite journal|last=Willis|first=Keith.D|date=|title=Paparazzi, Tabloids, and the New Hollywood Press: Can Celebrities Claim a Defensible Publicity Right in Order to Prevent the Media from Following their Every Move?|url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=edsglt&AN=edsgcl.174581867&site=eds-live&authtype=ip,guest&custid=s1226370&groupid=main&profile=eds|journal=Texas Review of Entertainment and Sports Law|volume=9|pages=175-202|via=}}</ref> <ref name=":152" /> Many state bills, such as California’s anti-paparazzi law, are set to protect celebrity privacy, while the [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]] of Constitution ensures the press’s freedom to express and gather information.<ref name=":17" /> <ref name=":152" /> In history, the balance of these two forces has been uncertain—sometimes the celebrities’ privacy requests outweigh the freedoms of press and expression, while other times the First Amendment is prioritized over celebrities who claim to be disrupted by the open press.<ref name=":17" />
=== United Kingdom === To prevent the royal family from being disrupted by the media, Britain set laws to restrict press reporting earlier than many other countries.<ref name=":102" /> Also, institutions like [[European Convention on Human Rights|the European Convention on Human Rights]] and the British Law Commission have been submitting proposals to protect individual privacy. <ref name=":102" />After the death of [[Diana, Princess of Wales|Princess Diana]] in 1997, the [[Press Complaints Commission]], a self-regulating organization of British media, proposed a series of regulations to prevent similar accidents from happening.<ref name=":102" /> The proposals include banning paparazzi photos taken through the continuous pursuit, expanding the definition of private property, strengthening the protection for celebrity children, and prevention of media collective harassment. <ref name=":102" />
=== France === According to Jamie Nordhaus, although the French government set strong laws to prevent paparazzi from invading celebrity privacy, these laws counteract with each other and thus are not efficient enough to protect celebrities and their children.<ref name=":102" /> The government prohibits paparazzi from publishing any photo that is not consented by the subjects but allows them to publish photos taken at public places. <ref name=":102" />Besides, the high profits resulted from publishing exclusive celebrity photos in France greatly exceed the $32,000 fine, which encourages French paparazzi to take risks.<ref name=":102" />
=== New Zealand === Similar to the U.S, Seong Hung argues that celebrities and their children in New Zealand are rarely protected by privacy laws for now.<ref name=":62" /> In 2004, Mr Hosking, a well-known television celebrity in New Zealand, sued the [[Pacific Magazine]] for taking and publishing the photos of his children, but the Court of Appeal ruled against Mr. Hosking by stating that the photographs did not invade the privacy right because they were taken in public spaces.<ref name=":62" />
== Other Laws regarding Celebrity Privacy == === The Right of Publicity === ==== United States ====
The [[Personality rights|right of publicity]], also called personality rights, aims to control and protect the unauthorized commercial use of people’s identity, such as name, photos, or likeness.<ref name=":122" /> Based on the right of privacy, the right of publicity is relatively new in the U.S—it was first recognized in the 1953 ''Haelan Laboratories v. Topps Chewing Gum'' case, and was later analyzed by Supreme Court in the 1977 [[Zacchini v. Scripps-Howard Broadcasting Co.|''Zacchini v. Scripps-Howard Broadcasting Co''.]]<nowiki/>case.<ref name=":122" /> The right of publicity is significant because with the advent of a new media age when “everyone can be famous on the Internet for 15 minutes”, the right of publicity becomes increasingly relevant and vital protection.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Mullins|first=Michael|date=|title=New Fame in A New Ballgame: Right of Publicity in The Ear of Instant Celebrity|url=https://journals.iupui.edu/index.php/inlawrev/article/download/18008/18126/0|journal=Indiana Law Review|volume=45|pages=869-95|via=}}</ref> This right is closely related to celebrity privacy because most of the time, it is used to protect celebrities from paparazzi or individuals who take the celebrities’ names and images for commercial use. Currently no [[federal law]] in the U.S protects celebrities’ right of publicity, however states like California have established [[statute]]<nowiki/>s and [[common law]] to protect their celebrity citizens. <ref name=":132">{{Cite journal|last=Whitehorn|first=Ellen.E|date=|title=Publicity, Privacy, and Fame: A Comparative Analysis of the Right of Publicity in the United States, Canada, and the U.K., Through the Lens of Kanye West's 'Famous'|url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=edsglt&AN=edsgcl.535005479&site=eds-live&authtype=ip,guest&custid=s1226370&groupid=main&profile=eds|journal=Transnational Law & Contemporary Problems|volume=27|pages=201-221|via=}}</ref> Keith Willis argues that the publicity right controversies often happen on celebrity product endorsement issues.<ref name=":122" /> ==== Canada ==== According to Ellen Whitehorn, Canada government protects the right of publicity, but the extent of the scope is still uncertain.The Courts protect individuals’ gaining from self-marketing, including name, images and personality, when it is violated.<ref name=":132" /> Similar to the U.S, the right of publicity laws mostly concentrate on different provinces: for example, [[Ontario]] has specific common laws which prevent the personality rights from being violated commercially.<ref name=":132" /> However, while the right of publicity in the U.S originates from the right to privacy, the personality right in Canada stems from [[Unfair competition|unfair competition law]].<ref name=":132" />
==== United Kingdom ==== Ellen Whitehorn claims that The United Kingdom currently does not have a specific legal statute to protect the right of publicity because, in history, U.K has been inclined to offer more protection for free speech and thus less focus on celebrity and their publicity rights. <ref name=":132" /> However, the U.K government still protects the right of publicity through other torts, such as some claims in the British Human Rights Act, [[Copyright infringement|violation of copyright]], or [[misuse of private information]]. <ref name=":132" />
=== Copyright === C[[copyright|opyright]] is also closely related to celebrity privacy. In the U.S, the Congress enacts copyright law based on Article 1(8)8 of the [[Constitution]], which suggest that authors have the exclusive right to their work in a limited period. <ref name=":142">{{Cite journal|last=Eaton|first=O'Neill|date=|title=Paparazzi/Blogger Face-Off: Opportunity Knocking for A Fair Use Limit?|url=https://heinonline.org/hol-cgi-bin/get_pdf.cgi?handle=hein.journals/caelj26&section=21|journal=Cardozo Arts&Entertainment Law Journal|volume=26|pages=535-558|via=}}</ref> The original work protected by copyright laws includes literacy work, artistic work, musical work, and dramatic work etc. <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Adams|first=John|date=2007-12-21|title=Originality in copyright: a solution to the database problem?|url=https://www.elgaronline.com/view/9781845424879.00005.xml|journal=Copyright Law|language=en-US|doi=10.4337/9781848440210.00005}}</ref> Since the producers of the original work are artists, musicians, or authors who are usually well-known, they are likely to be involved in copyright lawsuits, which could affect their rights of privacy. Besides, scholar O'Neill Eaton suggests that sometimes the press fights for the copyright of paparazzi photos to make most of the profits from exclusive celebrity images. In 2006, the famous U.S celebrity gossip blogger [[Perez Hilton]] was sued by paparazzi agency X17 because he posted photos taken by X17 onto his own website without permission.<ref name=":142" /> Perez has denied violated copyright laws, stating that his work falls under [[fair use]], as he uses the material for humor and satire. The Court final decision was that Perez’s use of the paparazzi photos violated the copyright laws, as Perez gained huge profits from publishing the paparazzi photos.<ref name=":142" />

[[File:Police in Estonia puiestee.JPG|thumb|400px|[[Law enforcement in Estonia|Estonian police]] in the capital [[Tallinn]].]] '''Crime in Estonia''' is combated by the [[Law enforcement in Estonia|Estonian police]] and other agencies.
== Crime by type == ===Murder=== {{See|List of countries by intentional homicide rate}}
In 2011, Estonia had a murder rate of 5.0 per 100,000 population.<ref name=UNODC/> There were a total of 65 murders in Estonia in 2011.<ref name=UNODC>[https://www.unodc.org/gsh/en/index.html ''Global Study on Homicide''. [[United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime]], 2013.]</ref>
An average of 9.4 people per 100,000 per year were killed in Estonia between 1999 and 2001.<ref name="Archer 2008"/>
===Organised crime=== Organized crime is characterized by a loose alliance of mobster groups, principally of Russian origins, with a wide range of different rackets: prostitution, motor vehicle theft, drug trafficking, and previously also "providing" workers to building contracts in Finland, where the criminal organizations were confiscating a share of workers' wages.<ref>http://www2.helsinginsanomat.fi/english/archive/news.asp?id=20020423IE11 Estonia's Obtshak crime organisation a major supplier of Finnish illegal drug market. Helsingin Sanomat 23.4.2002</ref> Although small, the mafia is hierarchical and well-organized, which has enabled its survival.<ref name="hs2017" />
====The Common Fund==== {{main|Obtshak}} The Common Fund ({{lang-et|Ühiskassa}}) is a traditional [[umbrella organisation]] of criminal groups, a trade union of sorts which settles conflicts and establishes the boundaries of the spheres of interest of the various groups. In 2003, the Common Fund had been dominated for about 15 years by Nikolai Tarankov of Ukrainian or Belarusian heritage and [[KGB]] training.<ref name='epl-2002'>[[Eesti Päevaleht]] February 11, 2002: [http://www.epl.ee/?artikkel=191821 Kuritegelik sõpruskond keerutab ühiskassa miljoneid ] by [[Risto Berendson]]</ref><ref>[[Eesti Ekspress]] March 12, 2003: [http://paber.ekspress.ee/viewdoc/7E1279E84A309C02C2256CE60047B4F5 Nikolai Tarankov – vaikne valitseja] by [[Raul Ranne]]</ref> However, Tarankov was killed by his godson in 2016.<ref name="hs2017">http://www.hs.fi/ulkomaat/art-2000005353261.html</ref> The Common Fund pays for lawyers of caught members, purchases and delivers packages to imprisoned members and covers other expenses.<ref name='epl-2002' /> Such "insurance" increases the loyalty of the members.<ref name="hs2017" />
In 2005, the Estonian Central Criminal Police noticed a decline in revenues of the Common Fund, leading to capture of several high-ranking members.<ref>[[Eesti Ekspress]] January 27, 2005: [http://paber.ekspress.ee/viewdoc/553624F5D1A7F13AC2256F8700448D76 Ühiskassa lahjad päevad] by [[Janar Filippov]]</ref> The decline has been attributed to changes in Estonian society, particularly those experienced in the lead-up to accession to [[European Union]].
In 2010s, the police have been successful in disrupting the operations of the Obtshak by arresting high-ranking members. One of the kingpins, Assar Paulus, was convicted in 2016 for founding a criminal organization and funding drug trafficking. The gang got its income through illegal debt collection and extortion, and some members committed tax fraud, drug crimes and violent crimes. In general, violent crime and protection rackets have become a thing of the past: it is no longer necessary for ordinary businessmen to pay protection money. Instead, the mafia is more involved in drug trade and white-collar crime such as tax fraud. Also, many former mafia "businessmen" have moved to legitimate business.<ref name="hs2017" />
===Fraud=== [[Aarni Neuvonen]] is the largest ever perpetrator of [[employment fraud]] in [[Estonia]]. He is known for having collected money with promise of overseas jobs from thousands of people and disappearing after having caused over (estimated) 10 million of [[Estonian kroon|EEK]] of damages in 1993. [[Avo Viiol]] was convicted for embezzlement in 2003. The neologism ''viioldama'', has become a [[slang]] veb meaning "to embezzle".<ref>[[Estonian Slang Dictionary]] maintained by [[Estonian Language Institute]]: [http://www.eki.ee/cgi-bin/sl_dic/?37 entry #37 ''to steal'']</ref>
=== Drugs ===
The illegal drug trade's turnover in Estonia according to 2008 estimates might be several billion [[Estonian kroon|EEK]]. According to the opinion of senior superintendent of narcotic crimes department at North Police Prefecture only 1% of the whole amount of drugs on the market is confiscated in Estonia.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://bbn.ee/Default2.aspx?ArticleID=2bbdfe03-5aeb-45f2-9cf0-1dc7f23ad5f3|title=Estonian narcotics market turnover exceeds EEK 5 billion|last=Koovit|first=Kaja|date=2008-10-03|work=Baltic Business News|accessdate=2009-06-14}}</ref> In 2011, the [[EUROPOL]] Trafficking Unit designated the Baltic states and Kaliningrad as a transit hub for drug trafficking in and out of Russia.<ref>[http://news.err.ee/db762b56-dc37-4374-8dc2-7f0cddec94bf Europol Assesses Baltic Organized Crime Hub], May 24, 2011</ref>
=== Corruption === {{main|Corruption in Estonia}} In 2008, [[Transparency International]] has measured the Corruption Perception Index for Estonia to be at 6.6 (CI 6.2–6.9), ranking it 27th in a list of 180 countries.<ref>[[Transparency International]]: [http://www.transparency.org/news_room/in_focus/2008/cpi2008/cpi_2008_table 2008 Corruption Perception Index] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090311002755/http://www.transparency.org/news_room/in_focus/2008/cpi2008/cpi_2008_table |date=March 11, 2009 }}</ref> In comparison, neighbouring Sweden was ranked 1st–3rd with a CPI at 9.3 (CI 9.2–9.4), Finland 5th–6th with a CPI at 9.0 (CI 8.4–9.4), Russia 147th–150th with a CPI at 2.1 (CI 1.9–2.5), and Latvia 52nd with a CPI at 5.0 (CI 4.8–5.2). Higher index means perception of more transparency and less corruption. As of 2014 the Corruption Perception Index for Estonia is 69, placing it at the 26th position (in the context of EU above France and below Austria).<ref>[[Transparency International]]: [http://www.transparency.org/cpi2014/results]</ref>
A total of 326 corruption-related offenses were identified and registered in 2008, considerably below the number registered in 2006, when 511 instances of corruption were found, but 17% higher than in 2007, and slightly higher than in 2003.<ref name = "Corruption - Ministry Report 2008">[http://www.korruptsioon.ee/orb.aw/class=file/action=preview/id=41353/Estonian+corruption+statistics+in+2008.pdf "Crime in Estonia in 2008."] Criminal Policy Studies No 10. Pp. 48–52 Tallinn: Ministry of Justice. Criminal Policy Department. 2009.</ref> These accounted for just 0.6% of all criminal offenses.<ref name="Corruption - Ministry Report 2008"/>
Foreign investors do not consider corruption as a main problem of doing business in Estonia. In general, the public sector is transparent and has good compliance with anti-corruption initiatives and demonstrates adherence to ethical principles on the cultural level.
In February 2012, the government passed an anti-corruption act in order to further improve transparency in the public sector, such as asset disclosure by government officials.<ref>{{cite web|title=Freedom in the world 2013- Estonia|url=http://www.freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2013/estonia|work=Freedom House|publisher=Freedom House|accessdate=17 November 2013}}</ref> Public trust in the electoral system is high. However, the government still faces challenges in combating corruption. Local-level government corruption still remains a problem, and public awareness of corruption-prevention needs to be raised.<ref>{{cite web|title=Snapshot of the Estonia Country Profile|url=http://www.business-anti-corruption.com/country-profiles/europe-central-asia/estonia/snapshot.aspx|work=Business Anti-Corruption Portal|publisher=GAN Integrity Solutions}}</ref>
===Human trafficking=== According to [[Interpol]] in 2002, since the fall of the Soviet Union the largest group of prostitutes working in Finland has consisted of trafficked women from Estonia and Russia.<ref>Leskinen, Jari. [http://www.interpol.int/public/THB/Women/situationReports/2002/finland.asp#1 "Finland Report 2002: Organised Pandering and Prostitution in Finland".] March 2003. Interpol. Retrieved June 6, 2009.</ref>
The 2012 "Trafficking in Persons Report" issued by the US Trafficking state department<ref>[https://www.state.gov/j/tip/rls/tiprpt/2012/192366.htm Trafficking in Persons Report 2012]</ref> repeats the claims of previous years that Estonia is "source, transit, and destination" for adult human trafficking, and that Estonia fails to comply with their minimum standards for eliminating trafficking. It now adds that the government "is making significant efforts to do so". Trafficking is now treated as a serious matter by the Estonian government, which enacted a law in 2012 criminalizing trafficking in persons with penalties of up to 15 years imprisonment. The Estonian government identified 56 victims in 2011; 39 women, 17 men, and no children; 37 were sex trafficking victims, 19 were labor trafficking.
The report also states that the Estonian government funds ($US42k) an active anti-trafficking hotline, and that it has increased funding ($US158k) for anti-trafficking victim care and that it maintains a "strong and supportive" relationship with organisations active in anti-trafficking. To this end the government has published a victim identification guide in Estonian and Russian, for use by law enforcement officials. The government has distributed anti-trafficking material at tourism and job fairs. Consular officials have visited schools to discuss dangers of trafficking. The government has also co-ordinated efforts in trafficking-reduction/elimination with other countries and has taken various other anti-trafficking measures.
== Crime dynamics == According to statistics published in Britain in 2008 relating to the period 1991–2001, the number of crimes increased by 84% from 1991 to 2001.<ref name = "Archer 2008">Archer, Clive. ''New Security Issues in Northern Europe: The Nordic and Baltic States and the ESDP''. London: Routledge, 2008. {{ISBN|0-415-39340-X}}, {{ISBN|978-0-415-39340-9}}. P. 25.</ref> The number of discovered [[drug-related crime]]s increased by 21 between 1997 and 2001.<ref name="Archer 2008"/> Overall, crime has fallen precipitously between 1995 and 2010, by close to 70%. <ref> https://www.economist.com/news/briefing/21582041-rich-world-seeing-less-and-less-crime-even-face-high-unemployment-and-economic </ref>
==Crime of Estonian residents overseas==
=== Jewellery robberies === In December 2006, it was estimated that residents of Estonia were responsible for 140 robberies of jewellery and watch stores in Finland, the Netherlands, Portugal, Italy, Spain, France, Germany, the United Kingdom, Denmark, and Sweden during the three years prior. The value of the lost property is estimated to be 25 million Euros.<ref>''Kuusi kultaryöstöa kahdessa vuodessa'', [[Helsingin Sanomat]], December 20, 2006, page A13</ref> In 2012, the ''Le gang des Estoniens'' was tried in France for robbing several jeweller's shops in Paris.

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=August 2018}} {{Infobox internet video | Name = Dekh Le | image = | caption = | Website = [[YouTube]] | Uploaded = {{Start date and age|df=yes|2013|12|16}} | Published = | Filmed = | Filmed by = Ketan Rana (director)
Aakash Raj (cinematographer) | Uploader = [[Whistling Woods International]] | Under the name= | Duration = {{Duration|h=0|m=1|s=36}} | Category = Film & Animation }} '''Dekh Le''' is a [[viral video]] dealing with the subject of men ogling women in India. It was produced by [[film studies]] students at [[Mumbai]]-based [[Whistling Woods International Institute|Whistling Woods International Institute of Film, Fashion & Media]] and released on 16 December 2013, the first anniversary of the [[2012 Delhi gang rape]]. It garnered one million hits in its first week on [[YouTube]]. ==Background== On 16 December 2012, a [[2012 Delhi gang rape|horrific gang-rape]] of an Indian girl took place in a moving bus in [[New Delhi]], the national capital of India. The event was followed by various [[protest]]s in which masses took to the streets in various Indian states, demanding the government to form stricter laws regarding women safety. The media industry voiced its concern in its own way. One such way was the women-empowerment [[ad campaign]] 'Dekh Le', launched one year after the incident. ==Content== The 90 second video shows four different scenarios where women are made to feel uneasy and uncomfortable by male gaze in everyday life situations. It shows women at a red light, in a bus, on a train and at a cafe, being subjected to staring male eyes. In order to retaliate, these women show mirrors to the men; on seeing how bad they look while staring at a girl, realize their mistake and are forced to take their eyes off. The video concludes with the four empowered women going about their business, free from prying eyes. {| class="wikitable" |+ '''Vignettes''' |- ! Victim-turned-empowered woman !! Offender(s) !! Offense !! Demonstration of empowerment !! Reflective device of shame |- | Twentysomething woman on a motorbike stopped at a traffic signal || Two twentysomething men on a motorbike who pull up alongside || Leering at the woman's thigh exposed by a slit in her [[short shorts]] || Sneer turned to scowl followed by a quick exit || Helmet [[visor]] which reflects the men's confusion |- | College-aged woman napping on a bus alongside a female companion || Three college-aged men standing in the aisle of the bus || One man calls the attention of the other two to the napping woman's [[Cleavage (breasts)|cleavage]]; one leans in for a look and they all smile knowingly || Pendant falls when the bus jostles the woman, obscuring her cleavage || Reflective [[pendant]] which reflects the instigator's regret |- | College-aged woman having a discussion with several friends at a cafe || Orange juice-drinking twentysomething man one table over || Staring at the woman's [[lower-back tattoo]] || Slinging her handbag over her back, covering the tattoo || Cosmetics mirror attached to the exterior of the [[handbag]] which startles the man |- | Thirtysomething woman sitting on a train, clad in a [[headscarf]] || Thirtysomething man in the seat across from her, [[snacking]] || Admiring the woman's face as she wipes the sweat from her brow || Look of disgusted disbelief followed by the donning of sunglasses || [[Sunglasses]] which reflect the man frantically looking about to see who has noticed his transgression |} == Song == The [[jingle]] was sung by famous Indian singer [[Sona Mohapatra]] and composed by [[Ram Sampath]]. The [[hook (music)|hook]] line "Dekh Le Tu Dekhta Hua Kaisa Dikhta Hai" translates as "Look how you look while you are looking at me." == Reception == The ad found a lot of media coverage, both on online news websites and blogs, as well as offline newspapers and magazines. Rheana Murray from [[New York Daily News]] described the video: "Video from Indian arts group shows leering men what they look like."{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/life-style/video-indian-ad-targets-leering-men-article-1.1556737#commentpostform |title=Video from Indian arts group shows leering men what they look like |publisher=NY Daily News |date=2013-12-23 |accessdate=2014-08-10}} Deepa Kunapuli from Upworthy wrote "It's meant to start a conversation about what empowerment for women looks like."{{cite web|author=Deepa Kunapuli |url=http://www.upworthy.com/this-ad-from-india-shows-men-exactly-how-creepy-they-are-when-they-stare-at-women-on-the-street |title=This Ad From India Shows Men Exactly How Creepy They Are When They Stare At Women On The Street |publisher=Upworthy.com |date= 2013-12-30|accessdate=2014-08-10}} Emma Cueto from Bustle writes, "The video is great, both in its very realistic – and uncomfortable – portrayal of men staring at young women, and also in the message it is trying to send. Hopefully it has a big impact, and not just in India."{{cite web|url=http://www.bustle.com/articles/11005-indian-ad-turns-the-male-gaze-back-on-itself-and-its-awesome |title=Bustle |publisher=Bustle |date=2013-06-07 |accessdate=2014-08-10}} Aditi Shome Ray from DNA described the ad: "This ad on women empowerment will make men cast their eyes down in shame."{{cite web|author=Aditi Shome-Ray |url=http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report-dekh-le-this-ad-on-women-empowerment-will-make-men-cast-their-eyes-down-in-shame-1939071 |title='Dekh Le': This ad on women empowerment will make men cast their eyes down in shame | Latest News & Updates at Daily News & Analysis |publisher=Dnaindia.com |date=2013-12-22 |accessdate=2014-08-10}} IBNLive described the ad as " The commercial sends out a strong message to show how ridiculous men look like while ogling at women."{{cite web|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/dekh-le-men-who-shamelessly-ogle-at-women-must-watch-this/440351-79.html |title=Dekh Le: Men who shamelessly ogle at women must watch this - IBNLive |publisher=Ibnlive.in.com |date= |accessdate=2014-08-10}} As of 1 August 2015, the video stands at more than five and a half million views on YouTube and has also hit the theatre screens of India.{{fact|date=August 2018}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{YouTube|SDYFqQZEdRA}} [[Category:2013 films]] [[Category:Feminism in India]] [[Category:Feminist films]] [[Category:Films about social issues in India]] [[Category:Indian short films]] [[Category:Public service announcements]] [[Category:Sexual harassment in India]] [[Category:Viral videos]]

{{Infobox NFL biography |name=Demetress Bell |image= |caption= |number=77 |position=[[Offensive tackle]] |birth_date={{birth date and age|1984|5|3|mf=y}} |birth_place=[[Summerfield, Louisiana]] |height_ft=6 |height_in=5 |weight_lbs=311 |high_school=[[Summerfield High School (Louisiana)|Summerfield (LA)]] |college=[[Northwestern State Demons football|Northwestern State (LA)]] |draftyear=2008 |draftround=7 |draftpick=219 |pastteams= * [[Buffalo Bills]] ({{NFL Year|2008}}–{{NFL Year|2011}}) * [[Philadelphia Eagles]] ({{NFL Year|2012}}) * [[Dallas Cowboys]] ({{NFL Year|2013}})* |pastteamsnote=yes |highlights= * All-[[Southland Conference|SLC]] (2007) * [[All-America]]n (2007) |statlabel1=Games played |statvalue1=40 |statlabel2=Games started |statvalue2=35 |nfl=BEL269922 }} '''Demetress Carte Bell''' (born May 3, 1984) is a former [[American football]] [[offensive tackle]]. After playing [[college football]] for [[Northwestern State University#Athletics|Northwestern State]], he was drafted by the [[Buffalo Bills]] in the seventh round of the [[2008 NFL Draft]]. He played for the Bills for four seasons. He is the son of former [[basketball]] star [[Karl Malone]].
==Early life== Bell, who spelled his first name "Demetrius" until 2012, when he learned his name was actually spelled "Demetress",<ref>{{cite news |author=McPherson, Chris |title=Eagles Fortify Tackle Spot With Bell |url=http://www.philadelphiaeagles.com/news/article-1/Eagles-Fortify-Tackle-Spot-With-Bell/0ea3f634-a34b-4e2d-96ab-27331d794098 |publisher=philadelphiaeagles.com |date=April 4, 2012 |accessdate=2012-04-04}}</ref> was born in 1984 to Gloria Bell, then aged 13, of Summerfield, Louisiana. According to Gloria Bell, Demetress' father is [[Karl Malone]], a former star player in the [[National Basketball Association]] (NBA) and a fellow native of Summerfield.<ref name="Fantin">Fantin, Linda. (1998, July 19). "Spirit vs. Letter of Law in Malone Paternity Suits", ''[[The Salt Lake Tribune]]''</ref> Malone and Demetress Bell have reportedly spoken on only one occasion.<ref name="Wilson">Wilson, Allen. (2008, April 29). "Dad Karl Malone a footnote in Demetrius Bell’s life", ''[[The Buffalo News]]''</ref>
As a young teenager, Bell played more softball than he did Malone's sport of basketball.<ref name="Fantin 2">Fantin, Linda. (1998, July 19). "Three Children Who Grew Up in the Shadow of Karl Malone", ''[[The Salt Lake Tribune]]''</ref> He did not play organized football at all during that time.<ref name="Ireland">Ireland, Doug. (2009, September 8). "[http://www.nsudemons.com/ViewArticle.dbml?ATCLID=204790117&DB_OEM_ID=20000 Demons' Demetrius Bell will start for Buffalo]", [http://www.nsudemons.com nsudemons.com] (Official website of the Northwestern State University Athletics Department)</ref> Eventually, during high school, he took up basketball and played well enough to receive a scholarship to [[Northwestern State University]], where he [[Northwestern State Demons|played]] in 88 games over the course of the 2003–04, 2004–05, and 2006–07 seasons.<ref name="Wilson" /> Bell was one of only four [[NCAA]] athletes to play both basketball and football in [[NCAA Division I|Division I]] in 2007.<ref>Crowe, Jerry. (2008, May 2). "[http://articles.latimes.com/2008/may/02/sports/sp-crowe2 Robinson's new plaque will have his place in history]", ''[[Los Angeles Times]]''</ref> After the 2006–07 season, he decided to give up basketball to concentrate on his development in football.<ref>"(2008, April 27). [http://www.southland.org/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=18400&ATCLID=1449212 Northwestern State's Demetrius Bell Taken In Seventh Round Of NFL Draft By Buffalo Bills]", [http://www.southland.org southland.org] (Official website of the Southland Conference)</ref>
==College career== Bell's high school had not fielded a football team, so prior to his attending Northwestern State, he had never played organized football. In the fall of 2005, he [[Redshirt (college sports)|red-shirted]] the basketball season and began playing for the school's football team. He was initially placed in the position of [[defensive end]]. The following year, injuries struck the team's offensive line, and he was moved to the [[Tackle (American football)#Left tackle|left tackle]] position. He earned second-team All-Louisiana honors that season.<ref name="Ireland" />
Bell made a bigger name for himself in his senior season of 2007, having focused solely on football. Remaining on the offensive line, he was named an All-Louisiana and an All-[[Southland Conference]] first-teamer. He also became an [[All-America#Collegiate sports|Associated Press All-American]].<ref name="Ireland" />
Bell graduated from Northwestern State in 2008.
==Professional career== ===Buffalo Bills (2008–2011)=== Bell was drafted by the [[Buffalo Bills]] in the seventh round of the [[2008 NFL Draft]].<ref name="Wilson" /> The Bills were encouraged by his raw skills, but saw him as a longer-term project, given his inexperience in having played organized football for only three seasons at that point.<ref>[[Associated Press]]. (2008, August 28). "[http://www.sportingnews.com/nfl/article/2008-08-28/bills-rookie-ot-bell-has-chance-start-vs-lions Bills rookie OT Bell has chance to start vs. Lions]"</ref><ref>Wilson, Allen. (2009, September 8). "[http://www.buffalonews.com/sports/story/761158.html Bell shining on Bills' O-line]", ''[[The Buffalo News]]''</ref> However, the team chose to place him on their active roster, rather than assigning him to their [[practice squad]], where he could potentially have been signed away by another team.<ref>Gaughan, Mark. (2008, August 31). "Bills keep Corto – Spragan, James, Wright released", ''[[The Buffalo News]]''</ref><ref>[[Associated Press]]. (2008, August 30). "[http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/wire?id=3561531&section=nfl Veteran CB James among notable cuts by Bills]"</ref> Consistent with their view of him as a work in progress, Bell was not activated for play in any of the Bills' regular season games in 2008.<ref>Wilson, Allen. (2009, January 14). "[http://www.buffalonews.com/sports/billsnfl/story/548697.html McKelvin’s wait with Bills was worth it]", ''[[The Buffalo News]]''</ref>
In 2009, citing the quality of Bell's performance in the Bills' off-season and pre-season [[Training camp (National Football League)|training camps]] that year, then-Bills head coach [[Dick Jauron]] installed Bell as the team's starting left tackle for the [[2009 Buffalo Bills season|2009 regular season]].<ref>Gaughan, Mark. (2009, September 10). "[http://www.buffalonews.com/sports/story/790614.html Bell won’t get ahead of himself]", ''[[The Buffalo News]]''</ref> After earning mixed reviews over the first half of the campaign, including an extremely high number of penalties against him, Bell's year came to a disappointing conclusion when he suffered what would prove to be a season-ending knee injury in a Week 10 game against the [[Tennessee Titans]].
===Philadelphia Eagles (2012)=== On April 4, 2012, the [[Philadelphia Eagles]] signed Bell to a contract that could be worth up to $34.5 million over five years. On February 6, 2013, Bell was released from his contract.<ref>profootballtalk.nbcsports.com/2013/02/06/eagles-dump-demetress-bell/</ref>
===Dallas Cowboys (2013)=== On July 21, 2013, Bell was signed by the [[Dallas Cowboys]].<ref>http://cowboysblog.dallasnews.com/2013/07/dallas-cowboys-officially-announce-signings-of-three-players-including-veteran-ot-demetress-bell.html/</ref> He was released by the Cowboys on August 31, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kffl.com/player/18630/nfl/news/demetress-bell |title=Demetress Bell |publisher=kffl.com |accessdate=September 12, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141205134054/http://www.kffl.com/player/18630/nfl/news/demetress-bell |archivedate=December 5, 2014 }}</ref>
==Relationship with Karl Malone== Karl Malone has never offered public confirmation that he is the father of Demetress Bell. However, laboratory blood tests prepared for the Bell family's 1996 [[Paternity (law)|paternity lawsuit]] against Malone reportedly pointed to an over 99 percent probability that Bell's father was either Malone or a brother of Malone. Malone initially refused to respond to the lawsuit, but eventually reached an out-of-court [[Settlement (litigation)|settlement]] with the Bell family over the issue. The Bells received a single lump sum payment of a confidential amount, with no on-going [[child support]] for Demetress. In speaking later about the settlement, Malone's attorney asserted that it had not included an official court determination of paternity, and noted that Malone "had a lot of brothers".<ref name="Fantin" />
Although Malone was 20 years old at the time that the 13-year-old Gloria Bell was impregnated, she said that her family chose not to pursue [[Statutory rape|criminal charges]] against Malone over the relationship. According to Bell, with Malone being a neighbor — Summerfield's population is only a few hundred — her family did not wish to see him jailed, especially since he would then be unable to provide any support for Demetress at all.<ref name="Fantin" />
In 2008, ''[[The Buffalo News]]'' published a story about Demetress Bell that included the claim that he didn't know who his father was until after he graduated from high school.<ref name="Wilson" /> However, in a 1998 article in ''[[The Salt Lake Tribune]]'', when Bell was 14 years old, his mother spoke of his shying away from anything to do with Malone because his feelings were hurt by Malone's refusal to acknowledge him.<ref name="Fantin 2" />
According to Bell, he has spoken to Malone on one occasion, when Bell was 18 years old. Bell reported that Malone told him that he would have to make his way on his own, as it was too late for the two men to have a father-son relationship.<ref name="Wilson" />
In 1989, Malone was also sued over the paternity of twins Daryl and [[Cheryl Ford]], also of Summerfield, Louisiana. Similarly to the case with Bell, the Ford twins' case was ultimately settled out of court and without Malone offering confirmation that he was the twins' father.<ref name="Fantin" /> In 1998, after knowledge of the two paternity suits became public, Malone did acknowledge his paternity of the Ford twins,<ref>Siegel, Lee. (1998, November 8). "Kay Malone Brings Message of Love To Families Panel", ''[[The Salt Lake Tribune]]''</ref> and he has since maintained an active relationship with them despite the ongoing estrangement between Bell and Malone. Bell has reported that he is very close to the Ford twins, who acknowledge him as their brother.<ref>[[Jemele Hill|Hill, Jemele]]. (2008, May 12). "[http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/page2/story?page=hill/080507 Karl Malone falls short, as a father]", [[Page 2|ESPN.com Page 2]]</ref>

{{Unreferenced|date=June 2008}} [[Image:Displace me X.jpg|thumb|Promotional poster]]
'''Displace Me''' was a nationwide event hosted by the nonprofit [[Invisible Children Inc]]. on April 28, 2007. In 15 cities across the [[United States]], 68,000 individuals came together to raise awareness about the situation of the [[Displaced persons camp|displacement camps]] in northern [[Uganda]].
The event had three main goals: #To educate participants about displacement camps in the North by simulating, as best as possible, the experience of living in an IDP camp. #To create greater national and international attention of the humanitarian crises in northern Uganda. #To garner the political attention needed to see a peaceful resolution to the [[Lord's Resistance Army insurgency]], primarily through the appointment of one senior level U.S. diplomat.
==The event== Displace Me was created to be an experiential event. To encourage the simulation, participants were asked to bring the following: *Enough cardboard to build something the size of a small tent. *A sleeping bag. *A 1.5-liter bottle of water (with an airtight seal—to be collected upon entry). *A box of saltine crackers (with sealed packaging—to be collected upon entry). *A current photo of you wearing a white T-shirt with a red X.
With 15 locations across the United States, participants had to travel long distances to reach their “camps.” The traveling aspect was reflective of the displaced individuals in northern Uganda who were given 48 hours to leave their homes and relocate to displaced camps throughout the region. Once Displace Me participants arrived at their camps, they built “huts” out of cardboard boxes. Throughout the remainder of the night, participants were rationed food and water and heard, via video, personal testimonies from those living in the IDP camps in the North.
Other aspects of the event included a speech at every city from an individual personally connected with the conflict. Speakers included the Gulu District Chairman [[Norbert Mao]], Invisible Children’s Ugandan Country Director '''Jolly Okot''', and the Senior Adviser to the International Crisis Group [[John Prendergast (activist)|John Prendergast]], among others. First Lady [[Laura Bush]] also directly addressed the Displace Me participants via a prerecorded speech shown on video. Participants concluded the night by writing letters to their government leaders and the President of Uganda, calling friends and family who were not aware of the conflict, as well as holding 21 minutes of silence for the 21 years of war.
During the night participants also helped film a video that was to be shown to members of the [[United States Senate]]. Participants in each city held up giant banners with their city's name and one to two phrases from the below statement.

The '''Field Naturalists Society of South Australia, Incorporated''' was founded in 1883 as a section of the [[Royal Society of South Australia|Royal Society]], and whose aims were to further the cause of the natural sciences in the colony. It was incorporated in 1959 and is still active. Membership is open to the public on application.
==History== In 1880 [[Samuel Way]], president of the [[Adelaide Philosophical Society]], which had just recently been granted permission to use the title "Royal Society of South Australia", lamented the lack of a local equivalent of the recently formed [[Field Naturalists Club of Victoria]] for keen amateurs to further the cause of natural sciences.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article43146453 |title=Adelaide Philosophical Society |newspaper=[[South Australian Register]] |volume=XLV, |issue=10,577 |location=South Australia |date=7 October 1880 |accessdate=3 October 2017 |page=2 (Supplement to the South Australian Register.) |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
The Association was formed as the "Field Naturalists' Section of the Royal Society of South Australia" (note apostrophe) on 14 November 1883, rules adopted and officers elected, many or most being members of the Royal Society: Chairman: Professor [[Ralph Tate]]; Vice-chairmen: Dr. [[H. T. Whittell]], and Rev. (later Professor) [[Walter Howchin]] FGS.; Hon. Secretary: W. E. Pickells.<ref>William Edward Pickells was a Melbourne insurance man who died by self-inflicted gunshot wound on 28 October 1904</ref> The foundation committee consisted of Dr. [[W. L. Cleland]], Dr. [[Wilhelm Haacke|W. Haacke]], [[J. G. O. Tepper]], A. Molineux, W. H. Selway, jun., G. Collis, jun., H. Dean, and G. F. Hussey.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article210519104 |title=General News |newspaper=[[The Express And Telegraph]] |volume=XX, |issue=5,958 |location=South Australia |date=14 November 1883 |accessdate=3 October 2017 |page=2 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> Another founding member of long standing was W. H. Baker.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article164878360 |title=First Branch of Royal Society |newspaper=[[The Observer (Adelaide)]] |volume=LXXXVI, |issue=4,477 |location=South Australia |date=13 April 1929 |accessdate=4 October 2017 |page=22 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> The first outing was to the Government Farm, Belair, on 24 November 1883.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article43604307 |title=Field Naturalists' Excursion |newspaper=[[South Australian Register]] |volume=XLVIII, |issue=11,555 |location=South Australia |date=26 November 1883 |accessdate=3 October 2017 |page=7 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref>

[[File:The Face of Fu Manchu.jpg|thumb|The Fu Manchu moustache, as worn by the eponymous fictional character.]] A '''Fu Manchu moustache''' or simply '''Fu Manchu''' is a full, straight [[moustache]] that originates on the corners of the mouth and grows downward past the clean-shaven lips and chin in two tapered "tendrils", often extending past the jawline.<ref>[http://www.americanmustacheinstitute.org/mustache-information/styles/ www.americanmustacheinstitute.org] ''Mustache Styles'' Retrieved Jan 30, 2011</ref> An expansion of the Fu Manchu sometimes includes a third long "tendril" descending from a small patch on the chin.
The Fu Manchu moustache derives its name from [[Fu Manchu]], a fictional character created by British/Irish author [[Sax Rohmer]], who is shown wearing such a moustache in film adaptations of Rohmer's stories. The literary Fu Manchu did not wear a moustache. The famous [[facial hair]] first appeared in the [[United Kingdom|British]] serial ''[[The Mystery of Dr. Fu Manchu]]'' (1923); the Fu Manchu moustache then became integral to cinematic and television [[Stereotypes of East and Southeast Asians in the United States#Fu Manchu: "evil" East Asian|stereotypical depictions of Chinese villains]].
The Fu Manchu is a category of competition in the [[World Beard and Moustache Championships]].<ref>[http://www.worldbeardchampionships.com/results/2009/ www.worldbeardchampionships.com] ''2009 Results – World Beard and Moustache Championships'' January 12, 2010. Retrieved Jan 30, 2011</ref><ref>[http://www.worldbeardchampionships.com/results/2010-european-championships-leogang-austria/ www.worldbeardchampionships.com www.worldbeardchampionships.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110225042406/http://www.worldbeardchampionships.com/results/2010-european-championships-leogang-austria/ |date=2011-02-25 }} ''Results – 2010 European Championships – Leogang, Austria'' October 8, 2010 Retrieved Jan 30, 2011</ref>
The facial hair style is often used to stereotype Asian, more specifically Chinese, ethnicity. Many caricatures of Chinese in the 19th and early 20th century depict Chinese with such facial hair.
==Confusion with horseshoe moustache== The Fu Manchu is similar to (and commonly confused with) the [[horseshoe moustache|horseshoe]] (or "biker") moustache; the difference between the two types is that the Fu Manchu is grown exclusively from the corners of the upper lip, creating two long "tendrils" that hang down past the clean-shaven mouth and chin area. The horseshoe simply involves growing the hair on either side of the lips and chin along with the mustache, thus creating the inverted-U or horseshoe shape, with none of the hair hanging over the jawline.
A true Fu Manchu is considerably more difficult and time-consuming to produce as compared to the horseshoe; one mustache-centered publication declares "You probably don't know anybody who has a [real] Fu Manchu."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.getkempt.com/high-and-tight/the-fu-manchu-vs-the-biker-mustache.php|title=The Fu Manchu vs. The Biker Mustache|author=|date=|website=getkempt.com|accessdate=15 April 2018}}</ref>

{{EngvarB|date=May 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} {{Refimprove|date=April 2009}} [[File:South-Africa Johannesburg Botanical Garden-012.jpg|thumb|200px|Commemorating 300 years of Huguenot history in South Africa]]
A large number of people of [[Europe]]an heritage in [[South Africa]] are descended from [[Huguenot]]s. Most of these originally settled in the [[Cape Colony]], but were absorbed into the [[Afrikaners|Afrikaner]] and [[Afrikaans]]-speaking population, because they had religious similarities to the Dutch colonists.
[[File:G.S. Smithard; J.S. Skelton (1909) - Huguehnots Building their Homesteads.jpg|thumb|Huguenots building their homesteads]] Even before the large-scale arrival of the Huguenots at the [[Cape of Good Hope]] in the 17th century, a small number of individual Huguenot refugees settled there. They included Francois Villion, later known as [[Viljoen]], and the du Toit brothers. In fact, the first Huguenot to arrive at the Cape of Good Hope was [[Maria de la Quellerie]], the wife of governor [[Jan van Riebeeck]], who started the settlement at the Cape of Good Hope in 1652 on behalf of the [[Dutch East India Company]]; however, she and her husband left for Batavia after ten years. After a commissioner was sent out from the Cape Colony in 1685 to attract more settlers, a more dedicated group of immigrants began to arrive. A larger number of French refugees began to arrive in the Cape after leaving their country as a result of the [[Edict of Fontainebleau]] (1685), which revoked the [[Edict of Nantes]] (1598) that had granted [[religious toleration]] to [[Protestants]].
On 31 December 1687 a group of Huguenots set sail from France as the first of the large scale emigration of Huguenots to the Cape of Good Hope, which took place during 1688 and 1689. In total some 180 Huguenots from France, and 18 Walloons from the present-day Belgium, eventually settled at the Cape of Good Hope. A notable example of this is the emigration of Huguenots from [[La Motte d'Aigues]] in Provence, France. After this large scale emigration, individual Huguenot immigrant families arrived at the Cape of Good Hope as late as the first quarter of the 18th century, and the state-subsidised emigration of Huguenots was stopped in 1706.
This small body of immigrants had a marked influence on the character of the Dutch settlers. They were purposely spread out and given farms amongst the Dutch farmers. Owing to the policy instituted in 1701 of the [[Dutch East India Company]] which dictated that schools should teach exclusively in [[Dutch language|Dutch]], that all official correspondence had to be done in Dutch, and strict laws of assembly, the Huguenots ceased by the middle of the 18th century to maintain a distinct identity, and the knowledge of French diminished and eventually disappeared as a home language.<ref name="Weiss1854">[https://books.google.com/books?id=CtPK8yS80IcC&pg=PA418&as_brr=1#PPA134,M1 ''History of the French Protestant Refugees, from the Revocation of the Edict of Nantes to our own days.''] M. Charles Weiss (Translated from the French by Henry William Herbert), 1854. New York: Stringer & Townsend.</ref> This assimilation into the colonial population was also due to the fact that many Huguenot descendants married individuals from the Dutch population.
==Franschhoek==
[[File:Franschoek Valley.jpg|right|thumb|Franschhoek Valley]]
Many of these settlers were allocated farms in an area later called [[Franschhoek]], Dutch for "French corner", in the present-day [[Western Cape]] province of South Africa. The valley was originally known as Olifantshoek ("Elephant's Corner"), so named because of the vast herds of elephants that roamed the area. The name of the area soon changed to ''le Coin Français'' ("the French Corner"), and later to Franschhoek, with many of the settlers naming their new farms after the areas in France from which they came. La Motte, La Cotte, Cabriere, Provence, Chamonix, Dieu Donne and La Dauphine were among some of the first established farms-—most of which still retain their original farm houses today.
{{clear}}
==Museum and monuments==
[[File:HuguenotMemorialMuseumBuilding.jpg|thumb|left|The Huguenot Museum in [[Franschhoek]].]] [[File:HuguenotMemorialMuseum.jpg|thumb|The [[Huguenot Monument]] of Franschhoek.]] {{main article|Huguenot Monument}} A large [[Huguenot Monument|monument]] to commemorate the arrival of the Huguenots in South Africa was inaugurated on 17 April 1948 at [[Franschhoek]]. A museum dedicated to the Huguenot history in South Africa is located adjacent to the monument.
A smaller monument commemorating the 300th anniversary of the arrival of the Huguenots is located in the [[Johannesburg Botanical Garden]].
{{clear}}
==Voortrekkers==
French Huguenot descendants were also included in the exodus of frontier farmers that was called the Great Trek.<ref>Bryer, Lynne and Theron, Francois. The Huguenot Heritage, The Story of the Huguenots at the Cape. Chameleon Press. Diep River. First Edition. 1987. Page 47.</ref>
Voortrekker surnames who were of French Huguenot ancestry include:<ref>Visagie, Jan C. Voortrekkerstamouers 1835 - 1845. Protea Boekhuis. Pretoria. 2011.</ref>-
(Original French spelling in brackets)

(Jacob?) *Jordaan (Jourdan) *Joubert (Jaubert) *Labuschagne (la Buscagne) *Le Roux *Lombard (Lombaard) *Malan (Mallan) *Marais *Maartens/Martins (Martin) *Malherbe *Minnaar (Meinard, Mesnard) *Meyer *Naude *Nel (Neel, Niel) *Nortier / Nortje (Nourtier) *Pienaar (Pinard) *Retief (Retif) *Reyneke? (Reyne?) *Riekert? (Richarde?) *Rossouw (Rousseau) *Roux *Senekal (Senecal, Senechal) *Terblanche (Terreblanque) *Theron (Therond) *Tredoux *Viljoen (Villion)
==Legacy== [[File:South-Africa Johannesburg Botanical Garden-011.jpg|thumb|300px|Surnames of Huguenot Families on the Huguenot Memorial in the [[Johannesburg Botanical Garden]]]]
There are many families, today mostly Afrikaans speaking, whose surnames bear witness to their Huguenot ancestry. A comprehensive list of these surnames can be seen on the Huguenot Memorial in the [[Johannesburg Botanical Garden]]. Examples of the more common names are Blignaut (''Blignault''), Cronje (''Cronier''), de Klerk (''Le Clercq''), Visagie (''Visage''), [[de Villiers]], du Preez, du Plessis, du Toit, du Randt, [[Fourie]], Fouche, Giliomee (''Guilliaume''), Gous / Gouws (''Gauch''), Hugo, [[Joubert]], Jordaan (''Jourdan''), Labuschagne (''la Buscagne''), Lange, [[Leroux (surname)|le Roux]], Leonard, Lombard, [[Malan (disambiguation)|Malan]], [[Michel (name)|Michel]], [[Malherbe (surname)|Malherbe]], Marais, [[Nel (name)|Nel]], Nortje (Nourtier), [[Pienaar]], Retief, [[Rossouw (disambiguation)|Rossouw]], Roux,<ref>{{cite book|last=van der Bijl|first=Johannes|title=Die Familie Roux|isbn=0-86965-464-0}}</ref> Terreblanche, Taljard, [[Theron (disambiguation)|Theron]] and [[Viljoen]] (''Villion'').<ref>Ces Francais Qui Ont Fait L'Afrique Du Sud. Translation: The French People Who Made South Africa. [https://www.amazon.fr/dp/2841000869 Bernard Lugan. January 1996.] {{ISBN|2-84100-086-9}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.museum.co.za/genealogy.html|title=Genealogy|publisher=The Huguenot Memorial Museum|accessdate=2009-04-20}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cNQ5AQAAMAAJ&lpg=PA274&pg=PA274 |title=The London Quarterly Review |volume=44 |chapter=William Shaw and South Africa |editor1-last=Watkinson |editor1-first=William Lonsdale |editor2-last=Davison |editor2-first=William Theophilus |publisher=J.A. Sharp |page=274 |year=1875 |access-date=7 July 2017 |via=Google Books}}</ref>
Some of the descendants of these original Huguenot families became prominent figures in South African society, most notably [[Frederik Willem de Klerk|F.W. de Klerk]], the last State President of [[apartheid]]-era South Africa.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2006/WORLD/africa/12/21/btsc.koinange.deklerk/index.html|title=De Klerk told Mandela: Timing of release not negotiable|last=Koinange|first=Jeff|date=21 December 2006|publisher=[[CNN]]|accessdate=2009-04-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/africa/the-new-south-africa-f-w-de-klerks-long-trek-470346.html|title=The new South Africa: F W de Klerk's long trek|date=18 March 2006|publisher=[[The Independent]]|accessdate=2009-04-21}}</ref> {{hidden begin |title = List of prominent South Africans of Huguenot descent |titlestyle = text-align:left;background:lightgrey;border:solid 1px grey;width:50%;padding:0.2em;margin: 0.5em 0 1em 0; |bodystyle = text-align:left;clear:left; }} ''Some of the original forms of the surnames have been put in brackets.'' * Aegidius Jean Blignaut, South African writer *[[Jan F. D. du Plessis]], poet *[[Ampie du Preez]], singer-songwriter *[[Frik du Preez]] ("du Prez"), Springboks rugby player, named as South Africa's rugby player of the 20th century *[[Max du Preez]], journalist and author *[[Alexander du Toit]], geologist *[[Daniel du Toit]], South African astronomer *[[Christiaan du Toit]], South African military commander *[[D. Malherbe]], Afrikaans novelist *[[Gideon Malherbe]], co-founder of an Afrikaans language movement named the Society of Real Afrikaners *[[Ben Marais]] *[[Eugene Marais]] *[[Sarie Marais]] *[[Beyers Naudé]], Afrikaner anti apartheid cleric. *[[Charle-Pierre Naudé]], poet *[[Jozua Naudé (politician)|Jozua Naudé]], acting President of South Africa from 1967 to 1968 *[[Francois Pienaar]], former [[South Africa national rugby union team|Springboks]] rugby player; captain of the first Springboks team to win the [[Rugby World Cup]] in [[1995 Rugby World Cup|1995]] *[[Piet Retief]], boer voortrekker *[[Esta TerBlanche]] ("Terre-Blanche") *[[Eugène Terre'Blanche]] ("Terre-Blanche"), South African political activist and leader of [[Afrikaner Weerstandsbeweging|AWB]] *[[Juan Theron]], South African cricketer *[[Charlize Theron]], [[Cinema of the United States|Hollywood]] actress *[[Totius (poet)|Totius]] (Jakob Daniël du Toit) – poet *[[Constand Viljoen]] ("Villion"), former leader of the South African Freedom Front (1994–2001) and SADF general *[[Gerrit Viljoen]] *H.D Viljoen (Former Inspector General SADF) *[[Marais Viljoen]] *[[Paul Visagie]], athlete and direct descendant of General [[Piet Joubert]] {{hidden end}}
Various French-language first names have also gained popularity amongst Afrikaners, examples being Francois, Jacques, Pierre, Charles and Eugene.
Some Afrikaans writers have Huguenot surnames, and were involved in setting up the [[Society of Real Afrikaners]].{{Citation needed|date=April 2009}}
The [[South African wine|wine industry in South Africa]] was greatly influenced by the Huguenots,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.overcomingapartheid.msu.edu/unit.php?id=11|title=Paths to Pluralism: South Africa’s Early History|publisher=[[Michigan State University]]|accessdate=2009-04-21}}</ref> many of whose families had owned [[vineyards]] in France.{{Citation needed|date=April 2009}} Many of the farms in the Western Cape province in South Africa still bear French names, such as [[Haute Cabrière]], La Petite Provence, La Bourgogne, La Motte, La Bri, La Borie, La Chataigne and La Roche.
